about.headline: Operator model with explicit boundaries
about.intro: Vionix runs short, constraint-led diagnostic engagements that establish baselines, validate safe improvement paths, and transfer operational ownership back to your team.

principles.title: Baseline before opinions
principles.text: Measure runtime, batch-window pressure, locks, deadlocks, regression frequency, and dependency hotspots before planning changes.

principles.title: Proof before persuasion
principles.text: Prototype 2-3 critical flows early to validate feasibility and expose hidden constraints before larger implementation effort.

principles.title: Risk-controlled delivery and handover
principles.text: Use parallel validation, explicit rollback paths, and practical guardrails, then transfer ownership through playbooks, templates, checks, and coaching.

about.weekOne: Week-1 outcome: a concise briefing (baseline + constraints), a prioritised plan, and one validated first-slice recommendation with risk controls.
goodFit: Slow reporting, overloaded databases, and lock-heavy data paths.
Fragile revenue modules with high regression risk and unclear ownership.
Delivery blocked by dependency sprawl, release pressure, or offline constraints.
notFit: Generic staff augmentation without a clear system outcome.
Greenfield MVP builds without production continuity constraints.
Full rewrites or cosmetic redesigns without operational goals.

engagements.intro1: Choose the format that matches current risk and delivery pressure. Each option produces concrete outputs and a clear next decision.
engagements.intro2: Engagements are usually principal-led. Additional specialists join only when explicitly scoped. The goal is measurable system outcomes and a clean handover to your internal owners.

cards.title: 1-Week Assessment
bullets: Baseline runtime, batch-window pressure, lock contention, and failure modes.
Map constraints, dependencies, and highest-risk execution seams.
Deliver a prioritised backlog and one validated first-slice recommendation.
cards.bestFor: Teams under immediate performance or reliability pressure with unclear technical constraints.
cards.typical: Baseline brief, constraints map, prioritised backlog, and one validated first-slice plan.
cards.window: Decision-ready scope and risk controls within one week.

cards.title: Implementation Sprint (2-4 Weeks)
bullets: Implement the first high-impact slice with measurable improvement targets.
Add guardrails, rollback paths, and production-safe rollout sequencing.
Leave a clear rollout plan for next slices and ownership handover.
cards.bestFor: High-risk modules where teams need measurable progress without service disruption.
cards.typical: Implemented first slice, guardrails, rollback strategy, and a sequenced rollout plan.
cards.window: Measurable reliability or runtime gains in 2-4 weeks.

cards.title: Enablement / Clinics
bullets: Harden review and release workflow with practical templates and checkpoints.
Increase onboarding speed and handover quality for high-change modules.
Improve release predictability through repeatable ownership routines.
cards.bestFor: Teams with inconsistent reviews, release friction, or fragile ownership transitions.
cards.typical: Review/release playbooks, onboarding templates, and repeatable ownership routines.
cards.window: Noticeable delivery predictability gains within the first month.

testimonials.quote: Stefan combines broad technical depth with practical execution discipline. He resolves complex problems quickly with clear, maintainable solutions.

Even under difficult conditions and significant time pressure, Stefan worked in a well-planned, efficient, and result-oriented way. He also defined quality objectives and monitored them through code reviews, version control, and testing.
Stefan showed strong ownership of his responsibilities, with consistent initiative, motivation, and clear goal orientation.
Stefan stood out through quick comprehension and dependable execution. His work was consistently thorough, reliable, and delivered with strong diligence.
The quality of Stefan's work was consistently and exceptionally high, and his contributions were recognized at the highest level.
After a short onboarding phase, Stefan handled tasks independently. He adapted quickly to an unfamiliar environment.
Stefan quickly became a go-to contact for other team members and worked with management in a cooperative, constructive way.
Stefan is persevering, motivated, and resilient, with a careful and precise way of working. Even under high workload, he remained highly reliable.
His conduct with both leadership and colleagues was consistently professional.
